  25  """ 
  26  Srikanth Pagadala's Note:  
  27  I ran into lot of performance issues with standard turtle library.  
  28  So I ended up patching it. This is my version of turtle. Next time please remind me to try pygame. 
  29  In the end, I'm very happy with how turtle based UI has turned out. I think I managed  
  30  to squeeze a good performance out of it. 
  31   
  32  Turtle graphics is a popular way for introducing programming to 
  33  kids. It was part of the original Logo programming language developed 
  34  by Wally Feurzig and Seymour Papert in 1966. 
  35   
  36  Imagine a robotic turtle starting at (0, 0) in the x-y plane. After an ``import turtle``, give it 
  37  the command turtle.forward(15), and it moves (on-screen!) 15 pixels in 
  38  the direction it is facing, drawing a line as it moves. Give it the 
  39  command turtle.right(25), and it rotates in-place 25 degrees clockwise. 
  40   
  41  By combining together these and similar commands, intricate shapes and 
  42  pictures can easily be drawn. 
  43   
  44  ----- turtle.py 
  45   
  46  This module is an extended reimplementation of turtle.py from the 
  47  Python standard distribution up to Python 2.5. (See: http://www.python.org) 
  48   
  49  It tries to keep the merits of turtle.py and to be (nearly) 100% 
  50  compatible with it. This means in the first place to enable the 
  51  learning programmer to use all the commands, classes and methods 
  52  interactively when using the module from within IDLE run with 
  53  the -n switch. 
  54   
  55  Roughly it has the following features added: 
  56   
  57  - Better animation of the turtle movements, especially of turning the 
  58    turtle. So the turtles can more easily be used as a visual feedback 
  59    instrument by the (beginning) programmer. 
  60   
  61  - Different turtle shapes, gif-images as turtle shapes, user defined 
  62    and user controllable turtle shapes, among them compound 
  63    (multicolored) shapes. Turtle shapes can be stretched and tilted, which 
  64    makes turtles very versatile geometrical objects. 
  65   
  66  - Fine control over turtle movement and screen updates via delay(), 
  67    and enhanced tracer() and speed() methods. 
  68   
  69  - Aliases for the most commonly used commands, like fd for forward etc., 
  70    following the early Logo traditions. This reduces the boring work of 
  71    typing long sequences of commands, which often occur in a natural way 
  72    when kids try to program fancy pictures on their first encounter with 
  73    turtle graphics. 
  74   
  75  - Turtles now have an undo()-method with configurable undo-buffer. 
  76   
  77  - Some simple commands/methods for creating event driven programs 
  78    (mouse-, key-, timer-events). Especially useful for programming games. 
  79   
  80  - A scrollable Canvas class. The default scrollable Canvas can be 
  81    extended interactively as needed while playing around with the turtle(s). 
  82   
  83  - A TurtleScreen class with methods controlling background color or 
  84    background image, window and canvas size and other properties of the 
  85    TurtleScreen. 
  86   
  87  - There is a method, setworldcoordinates(), to install a user defined 
  88    coordinate-system for the TurtleScreen. 
  89   
  90  - The implementation uses a 2-vector class named Vec2D, derived from tuple. 
  91    This class is public, so it can be imported by the application programmer, 
  92    which makes certain types of computations very natural and compact. 
  93   
  94  - Appearance of the TurtleScreen and the Turtles at startup/import can be 
  95    configured by means of a turtle.cfg configuration file. 
  96    The default configuration mimics the appearance of the old turtle module. 
  97   
  98  - If configured appropriately the module reads in docstrings from a docstring 
  99    dictionary in some different language, supplied separately  and replaces 
 100    the English ones by those read in. There is a utility function 
 101    write_docstringdict() to write a dictionary with the original (English) 
 102    docstrings to disc, so it can serve as a template for translations. 
 103   
 104  Behind the scenes there are some features included with possible 
 105  extensions in mind. These will be commented and documented elsewhere. 
 106   
 107  """

 210                  if "." in value: 
 211                      value = float(value) 
 212                  else:

 215                  pass # value need not be converted 
 216          cfgdict[key] = value

 266      Derived from tuple, so a vector is a tuple!

 268      Provides (for a, b vectors, k number):

1887          >>> turtle.circle(120, 180)  # semicircle 
1888          """ 
1889          if self.undobuffer: 
1890              self.undobuffer.push(["seq"]) 
1891              self.undobuffer.cumulate = True 
1892          speed = self.speed() 
1893          if extent is None: 
1894              extent = self._fullcircle 
1895          if steps is None: 
1896              frac = abs(extent)/self._fullcircle 
1897              steps = 1+int(min(11+abs(radius)/6.0, 59.0)*frac) 
1898          w = 1.0 * extent / steps 
1899          w2 = 0.5 * w 
1900          l = 2.0 * radius * math.sin(w2*math.pi/180.0*self._degreesPerAU) 
1901          if radius < 0: 
1902              l, w, w2 = -l, -w, -w2 
1903          tr = self.tracer() 
1904          dl = self._delay() 
1905          if speed == 0: 
1906              self.tracer(0, 0) 
1907          else: 
1908              self.speed(0) 
1909          self._rotate(w2) 
1910          for i in range(steps): 
1911              self.speed(speed) 
1912              self._go(l) 
1913              self.speed(0) 
1914              self._rotate(w) 
1915          self._rotate(-w2) 
1916          if speed == 0: 
1917              self.tracer(tr, dl) 
1918          self.speed(speed) 
1919          if self.undobuffer: 
1920              self.undobuffer.cumulate = False
